content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Sunhee Kim: I was born in Los Angeles, but I grew up in a small town in the Pacific region, where my parents had moved for work. My childhood was pretty typical for someone from a middle-class family—my parents both had bachelor's degrees, and while we weren't wealthy, we were never lacking for love or support. My mom worked as a teacher, and my dad was in engineering. They always encouraged me to pursue my education, which I did. I went to a public school, and I was pretty good at math and science, but I also loved literature and writing. I remember staying up late reading novels and writing stories in my journal. I moved to Irvine when I was 16, and while I missed the small-town feel, I adapted quickly. I went to college here, got my bachelor's degree in business administration, and eventually found a job in marketing. I met my husband during a volunteer event at a local church, and we got married a few years later. Life has been busy, but I wouldn't trade it for anything. I speak Korean at home with my parents, and I still keep in touch with my old friends from the Pacific. I like to think I've built a life that's both stable and full of opportunities.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Sunhee Kim: Yes, there was a moment that really shaped my path. After I graduated from high school, I had two main options: attend a local community college or move to a bigger city for a more competitive university. I was torn because I wanted to stay close to my family and friends, but I also knew that if I wanted to build a career in business, I needed to be in a place with more opportunities. I ended up choosing to move to Irvine for college, which was a big step for me. It wasn't easy—adjusting to a new city, making new friends, and balancing school with part-time work was challenging. But I remember one specific moment during my first semester when I was sitting in a business class, and the professor asked us to think about our long-term goals. I realized then that I didn't want to be stuck in a small town with limited options. That moment pushed me to work harder, get involved in campus activities, and eventually land an internship that led to my first full-time job. It was a crossroads, and choosing to move forward with courage was the best decision I ever made.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Sunhee Kim: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made easily. I had a lot of doubts and fears, especially because I was leaving everything familiar behind. But I remember talking to my parents one evening, and my mom said something that stuck with me: 'Sunhee, life is like a river—it doesn't always flow smoothly, but it moves forward.' That gave me the courage to take the leap. I didn't just choose to move to Irvine; I chose to believe in myself and my future. It wasn't just about the opportunities—it was about growing into the person I wanted to be. And looking back, I know that decision was the foundation of who I am today.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Sunhee Kim: Absolutely. My high school guidance counselor, Ms. Park, was someone who really believed in me when I wasn't sure I believed in myself. She sat down with me during my junior year and talked about the importance of thinking beyond the immediate comfort zone. She even helped me apply for scholarships and connect with mentors at local businesses. Without her support, I might have stayed in the Pacific and never considered moving to Irvine. Also, my church community played a role. When I was struggling with the decision, the pastor invited me to lead a youth discussion group, which gave me confidence in my ability to lead and communicate. Those people and organizations didn't just help me make the move—they helped me grow into the person I needed to become.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Sunhee Kim: Yes, I'm married to a wonderful man named David, whom I met through a volunteer event at our church. We got married five years ago, and we have a three-year-old daughter named Sophia. She's a bright and curious child who loves drawing and asking questions about everything. David works in IT, and while our careers are different, we both value hard work and family. We live in a quiet neighborhood in Irvine, and I enjoy being close to my in-laws as well. My parents still live in the Pacific, and we make it a point to visit them at least once a year. Family has always been important to me, and I try to instill that value in Sophia. I think the strongest thing about our family is that we support each other through every challenge and celebrate each success, no matter how small.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 1 to 5, I realize how much my journey has been shaped by both personal choices and the support of others. Talking about my life story reminded me of how far I've come—from a small town in the Pacific to building a stable and fulfilling life in Irvine. The crossroads I faced after high school was a pivotal moment that tested my courage and belief in myself, and it's amazing how that decision set the foundation for who I am today. I'm grateful for the guidance I received from people like my high school counselor and my church community, who helped me take that leap of faith. Now, as a wife and mother, I see the importance of family and support systems more clearly than ever. These reflections remind me that every step, every challenge, and every person who believed in me has played a role in shaping my story.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Sunhee Kim: My immediate family includes my younger brother, Michael, who is 10 years my junior. He's always been the adventurous one in our family—while I was the one who stayed up late reading, he was the one who would climb trees and ride his bike down hills without a helmet. He's now a graphic designer in San Francisco, and though we don't see each other as often as I'd like, we keep in close contact through calls and video chats. Our relationship has always been filled with teasing and inside jokes, but there's a deep respect there too. He was the one who encouraged me to take risks when I was younger, and I think that influence helped me make the decision to move to Irvine. Even now, he's one of the first people I call when I'm facing a big decision. Family, for me, isn't just about being together—it's about knowing you have someone who believes in you, even when you're not sure you believe in yourself.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Sunhee Kim: Outside of my family, there are a few friends who have been incredibly important to me over the years. One of them is Lisa, who I met in college. We were in the same business club, and she became one of my closest friends. Lisa is a marketing strategist now, and she's always been the one to push me to think creatively and take on new challenges. Even though we're both busy with our careers, we still make time for each other—whether it's grabbing coffee or planning weekend trips. There's also my college roommate, Emily, who I haven't talked about much. She moved back to her hometown after graduation, but we stay in touch. She's the one who introduced me to the idea of traveling more, and we've been planning a trip to Japan for the past two years. It's funny how some of the people we meet along the way can shape our perspectives and dreams in ways we never expected. I'm grateful for all of them—they've been like family in many ways, offering support, laughter, and sometimes even tough love when I needed it most.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Sunhee Kim: I live in a quiet neighborhood in Irvine called Woodbridge, which is known for its tree-lined streets, community parks, and a strong sense of neighborhood pride. It's a mix of families, professionals, and retirees, which gives the area a really warm and welcoming vibe. Our street, Ocean View Drive, is close to a local park where Sophia loves to play on the swings and slide. I also appreciate how walkable the neighborhood is—there are plenty of cafes, grocery stores, and even a small library within a few blocks. What I love most about living here is the balance between being close to the city's opportunities and still having the peace and safety of a suburban feel. It's a place where I can feel grounded, and I think it's helped us build a stable life for our family. Plus, being near the beach is a bonus—on weekends, David and I like to take Sophia to the shore for a picnic or a walk along the water. It's a small thing, but it makes life here feel special.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Sunhee Kim: I definitely feel very safe in our neighborhood. It's one of the reasons we chose to live here. The streets are well-lit, and there's a strong sense of community—neighbors know each other, and people look out for one another. I've never felt uneasy walking around, even after dark. There are community events throughout the year, like the local farmers' market and holiday festivals, which bring everyone together. I think the safety here is more than just the physical aspect; it's the feeling of belonging and trust that makes this place feel secure. It's comforting to know that if something were to happen, there are people nearby who would help. For a family with a young child, that sense of safety is invaluable—it allows us to focus on building a life without constant worry.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Sunhee Kim: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, the sense of community and the safety of the neighborhood have made it easy for us to build a stable life for our family. I love that Sophia can ride her bike around the block without me worrying about her safety, and that I can walk to the park or the grocery store without hesitation. The local schools are also excellent, which gives me peace of mind about her future. That said, living in a suburban area does have its challenges. Sometimes, I feel like the pace of life here is a bit slower than what I'm used to, especially with my career in marketing, where things can move quickly. There are also moments when I miss the cultural diversity of the city—like the bustling Korean markets or the vibrant street food scene. But I've learned to find balance. I make it a point to visit downtown Irvine or even go to Los Angeles for cultural events or to catch up with friends. It's all about making the most of what this place offers while staying connected to the parts of life that matter most to me.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 6 to 10, I realize how much my family and neighborhood have become the foundation of my current life. Talking about my partner, David, and our daughter, Sophia, reminded me of how much love and support shape our daily lives. Our family is my greatest source of strength, and knowing that we have each other through every challenge makes all the difference. When I shared about our neighborhood in Woodbridge, I was reminded of how important it is to feel safe and connected to the community. Living here has given us stability, and the sense of belonging I feel in this place is something I truly cherish. It's amazing how the people around us—both family and neighbors—create a life that feels full, secure, and meaningful. I'm grateful for every part of it.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Sunhee Kim: A typical week for me is pretty structured, but it varies depending on work deadlines and Sophia's schedule. On weekdays, I usually wake up around 6:30 a.m., make breakfast, and get Sophia ready for preschool. I drop her off and head to the office, where I work as a marketing manager for a mid-sized tech company. My days are usually filled with meetings, strategy sessions, and managing a team of five. I try to take a lunch break, even if it's just a quick walk in the park nearby. In the afternoons, I pick up Sophia and we spend the rest of the day together—sometimes we go to the library, have a playdate with friends, or just relax at home. On weekends, we like to explore the area—whether it's a visit to the beach, a family brunch, or a trip to a local museum. David usually works from home on Fridays, so we try to make that day special with something fun, like a picnic or a movie night. I also make time for myself, whether it's reading, practicing yoga, or catching up with friends. It's not perfect, but it's a rhythm that works for our family.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Sunhee Kim: I work as a marketing manager for a mid-sized tech company here in Irvine, and I'm typically on the clock from around 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., Monday through Friday. My role involves developing campaigns, managing a team, and collaborating with different departments to ensure our brand stays visible and relevant in a competitive market. I've been in this position for about three years now, and it's been a great fit for me—challenging, but also rewarding. I enjoy the creative aspects of the job, like brainstorming new ideas or working on digital campaigns that reach a wide audience. That said, the hours can be long, especially when we're launching a new product or preparing for a big event. I've had to learn how to balance work with family life, and I'm grateful that my employer is pretty flexible when it comes to remote work or adjusting schedules for important family moments. It's not always easy, but I try to stay organized and make time for what matters most—whether that's a project deadline or a bedtime story for Sophia.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Sunhee Kim: Outside of work and family, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. I try to practice yoga at least three times a week, usually in the early morning before the day gets too busy. It's my way of starting the day with intention and keeping my stress levels in check. I also enjoy cooking, especially experimenting with Korean recipes—my mom taught me how to make kimchi and bibimbap when I was younger, and I love sharing those meals with David and Sophia. On the weekends, I like to spend some time volunteering at the local community center, where I help organize events for families and kids. It's a small way to give back, and it reminds me of the support I received when I was younger. I also make it a point to read at least one book a month, usually fiction or self-help. It's amazing how much those little routines contribute to my sense of balance and well-being. They might seem simple, but they're the things that help me feel like I'm living a full and intentional life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Sunhee Kim: One of the more recent changes to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I started using a meditation app a few months ago, and it's helped me become more present and less reactive, especially during busy workdays. I also began taking Sophia to a local community garden on weekends, where we plant vegetables and learn about nature together. It's been a nice way to connect with her and teach her about responsibility and growth. Another change is that I've started setting aside time each evening to journal—just a few minutes before bed to reflect on the day, express gratitude, or jot down ideas for work or family. It's a small shift, but it's made a big difference in how I approach each day with more clarity and intention.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Sunhee Kim: Sophia's typical weekday during the school year starts early—she's usually up by 7:00 a.m., and we have a routine of breakfast, brushing teeth, and getting dressed. She goes to a local preschool that's just a few blocks away, and her days are filled with play, art, and basic academics. The teachers there are wonderful, and they send home little notes about her progress, which I love reading. After school, she comes home around 3:00 p.m., and we have a snack, then she has some free time to play or do homework if needed. On most days, she participates in a creative arts class at the community center twice a week, where she gets to paint, make crafts, and even try out simple dance moves. I also try to take her to the library once a week, and she's become quite the bookworm—she loves picture books with animals and adventures. On some afternoons, she has playdates with friends, and we usually end the day with a family dinner and a bedtime story. It's a busy but sweet rhythm, and I see how much she's growing and learning every day.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 11 to 15, I realize how much my daily life and routines have become a reflection of the balance I strive to maintain between work, family, and personal well-being. Talking about my family and neighborhood reminded me of how deeply rooted I am in the life I've built here in Woodbridge. It's not just about the stability of the place, but also the people who make it feel like home—David, Sophia, my parents, my brother, and the friends who have been there through every chapter of my life. When I shared about my job as a marketing manager and the structure of my week, it became clear how much I've learned to juggle the demands of my career with the joys of being a mother and a wife. The routines I've developed—like practicing yoga, cooking Korean meals, and volunteering—aren't just habits; they're the things that keep me grounded and connected to who I am. I'm grateful for the small changes I've made, like incorporating mindfulness and journaling, because they remind me to slow down and appreciate the present. These reflections have shown me that life is a mix of structure and spontaneity, and it's in that balance that I find peace and purpose.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Sunhee Kim: In terms of my health, I would say I'm generally in good shape, though I've had my share of ups and downs over the years. I've always been pretty active, even as a kid—I used to run around the neighborhood with my brother, and I still enjoy being outdoors. When I was in college, I wasn't as mindful about my health, and I did struggle with some stress-related issues, like occasional anxiety and insomnia. That's when I started incorporating yoga and mindfulness into my routine, which has made a huge difference. I also try to eat well, mostly sticking to a balanced diet with lots of vegetables, lean proteins, and whole grains. I've always loved Korean food, so I make sure to include traditional dishes like kimchi, bibimbap, and soups in my meals. I do have some health concerns, like high blood pressure, which I manage through regular check-ups and medication. I also take supplements like magnesium and vitamin D, especially during the colder months. Overall, I believe in taking a proactive approach to my health, and I try to lead by example for Sophia. I want her to grow up knowing that taking care of your body and mind is just as important as anything else in life.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Sunhee Kim: For me, staying healthy is both easy and challenging in different ways. On the one hand, I have a strong support system—my family and friends remind me to take breaks, eat well, and not push myself too hard. I also have routines that make it easier, like my morning yoga and the meals I prepare at home. But on the other hand, work can be stressful, and there are days when I get caught up in deadlines and forget to prioritize my well-being. I also struggle with consistency, especially when it comes to sticking to my exercise routine or making time for self-care. I've learned that small changes, like taking short walks during lunch or drinking more water throughout the day, can make a big difference. What makes it harder is the temptation to skip the healthy habits when life gets busy, but I remind myself that taking care of my health is not a luxury—it's a foundation for everything else in my life, including being there for my family and doing the work I love.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Sunhee Kim: In the past two years, I actually had a minor health scare that reminded me how important it is to stay proactive. About a year ago, I started experiencing some persistent back pain, which I initially thought was just from sitting at my desk too long. But after a few months of discomfort, I finally made an appointment with my doctor. It turned out that I had developed a herniated disc in my lower back, likely from years of poor posture and not taking enough breaks during long work hours. The doctor recommended physical therapy, which I started immediately. I also had to adjust my workspace to be more ergonomic—adding a standing desk and a supportive chair made a huge difference. It was a bit of a setback, but it also became a turning point for me. I started prioritizing movement more, like taking short walks during the day and even joining a local fitness class for beginners. The pain has mostly subsided now, and I feel much stronger. It was a tough experience, but it taught me that even small changes can have a big impact on your health. I'm grateful that I caught it early and that I have the support of my family and friends to help me through it.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Sunhee Kim: Honestly, the back pain did make things a little more challenging for a while. There were days when I had to take it easy at work, or even stay home with Sophia when the pain was too intense. I remember one particular week when I had a big project deadline, and I was struggling to focus because of the discomfort. It was hard to be fully present for my team or for Sophia, and I felt guilty about it. But what I learned from that experience was that it's okay to ask for help—whether it's from my husband, my doctor, or even my colleagues. David took on more of the parenting duties during that time, and my team was incredibly understanding. It reminded me that health isn't just about being strong or independent; it's also about knowing when to slow down and let others support you. Now, I'm more mindful of how my body feels, and I try to listen to it before it becomes a bigger issue. It's not perfect, but I'm grateful for the lesson it taught me about balance, self-compassion, and the importance of a strong support system.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Sunhee Kim: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—some days I feel incredibly grateful for the life I've built, and other days I feel the weight of balancing so many responsibilities. I think the biggest thing that's changed for me is how I approach challenges. After dealing with the back pain and learning to slow down, I've become more intentional about how I spend my time and energy. I've also noticed that Sophia is growing up so fast, and I find myself cherishing every moment with her more than ever. There's a sense of peace in knowing that we've created a stable, loving home for her, even as life continues to change. I've also been more reflective about my own goals and what I want for the future. I'm thinking about maybe going back to school for a master's degree in marketing, something I've always wanted to do but never had the time for. It's exciting but also a bit daunting. Overall, I feel like I'm in a good place—rooted in my family, connected to my community, and still hopeful for what's next.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 16 to 20, I realize how much my health and well-being have become a priority in my daily life. Talking about the changes I've made to my routine—like incorporating mindfulness, journaling, and spending time in the community garden—reminded me of how small, intentional shifts can have a big impact on my overall sense of balance. It also brought up the challenges of maintaining healthy habits, especially when work gets busy or life feels overwhelming. Sharing about my recent back pain and how it affected my ability to work and care for Sophia was a humbling experience, but it also taught me the importance of listening to my body and asking for help when needed. I've come to see health not just as something to manage, but as a foundation for everything else in my life—my career, my family, and my personal growth. It's comforting to know that I have a strong support system in place, and I'm more committed than ever to taking care of myself so I can continue being there for the people I love.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Sunhee Kim: I think I've had moments of anxiety, especially during the busier times in my career or when I was dealing with the back pain. There were days when I felt overwhelmed by the demands of work, family, and trying to stay healthy all at once. But I've learned to recognize those feelings and not let them define me. I've started talking more openly about how I feel with my husband and friends, and that's helped a lot. I also try to stay connected to my faith, which gives me a sense of calm and perspective. I don't think I've ever experienced full-blown depression, but I do believe in the importance of mental health and taking care of it just as seriously as physical health. I've even started seeing a therapist occasionally, which has been really helpful in navigating the challenges of being a working mother and maintaining my own sense of identity. It's not always easy, but I'm learning to be kinder to myself and to seek support when I need it.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Sunhee Kim: For my family, the past year has been a mix of growth, challenges, and moments of deep connection. David has been incredibly supportive, especially during the time I was dealing with my back pain. He took on more of the parenting duties, and I'm so grateful for his patience and understanding. Sophia has been growing so quickly—it feels like just yesterday she was a baby, and now she's full of curiosity and questions about the world. She's starting to express her own opinions, which is both exciting and a little overwhelming at times. Our family has also been navigating some changes, like adjusting to new routines as she starts kindergarten next year. We've been preparing her for that transition, and it's been a team effort. My parents still visit us every year, and it's always a joy to have them here. They've been helping with Sophia during their visits, which gives me a little more time to focus on work or rest. Overall, I feel like we're all learning to adapt and support each other through the changes life brings. There have been tough moments, but there's also a lot of love and gratitude in our home.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Sunhee Kim: For me, religion has always been a source of strength and guidance. I was raised Protestant, and even though I don't attend church as frequently as I used to, my faith is still a big part of who I am. It's not just about going to services or following rules—it's about the values I was taught growing up, like kindness, humility, and the importance of community. My church family has been there for me through every major life event, from my wedding to Sophia's birth. Even now, when life gets overwhelming, I find comfort in prayer and scripture. I also try to live out my faith in practical ways, like volunteering or being there for others when they need support. I think spirituality is about more than just belief—it's about how you show up in the world and treat the people around you. It's something I want to pass on to Sophia, not just as a set of beliefs, but as a way of life.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Sunhee Kim: I actually use social media quite a bit, but more for staying connected with family and friends than for the wider world. I have a Facebook account where I keep in touch with my parents, my brother, and some of my old friends from the Pacific. I also use Instagram, but mostly to share little moments from Sophia's day—like her first steps, her favorite drawings, or just her smiling at something silly. I find it comforting to see her growth through those photos, and it's also a way for me to share her joy with people who can't be with us every day. I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through news or trends, though—I think it's important to be mindful of how much time I give to social media. I do follow a few local community pages and some Korean food bloggers, which keeps me connected to both my culture and my neighborhood. It's not perfect, but I like how it helps me stay rooted in the things that matter most to me.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Sunhee Kim: Honestly, I haven't used social media as a source of emotional or financial support during tough times, but I can see how it might help others. For me, it's more about staying connected with the people I already care about rather than seeking out strangers for support. That said, there were a few times when I posted about my back pain or the challenges of being a working mom, and I was surprised by how many people reached out with encouragement or even shared their own stories. It wasn't the kind of support I would have expected, but it was meaningful in its own way. I think social media can be a double-edged sword—it can bring people together or make you feel more isolated, depending on how you use it. For me, it's been a tool for connection rather than a crutch, and I'm grateful for the small ways it helps me feel less alone.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 21 to 25, I realize how much my health journey has shaped my perspective on balance, self-care, and the importance of support systems. Talking about my herniated disc and the challenges it brought to my work and parenting reminded me of how fragile our health can be, and how crucial it is to listen to our bodies before they signal us to stop. It also made me more aware of the emotional toll that health issues can take, especially when they interfere with the roles we hold in our families and careers. Sharing about my anxiety and the steps I've taken to manage it—like therapy, mindfulness, and leaning on my faith—has helped me see that mental health is just as important as physical health. I've come to understand that asking for help is not a sign of weakness, but a reflection of strength and self-awareness. These reflections have deepened my gratitude for my family, friends, and the small but meaningful changes I've made to prioritize my well-being. I'm learning that life is not about perfection, but about showing up for ourselves and others with intention, compassion, and resilience.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Sunhee Kim: In the past year, I've noticed that my stress levels have fluctuated, but I've been more intentional about how I manage it. There were definitely moments when I felt overwhelmed, especially when juggling work deadlines, Sophia's growing needs, and my own health recovery. But I've started relying more on the coping strategies I've developed over time—like mindfulness, journaling, and talking things through with David or my therapist. I've also found that setting small, achievable goals for myself has helped reduce the feeling of being pulled in too many directions at once. For example, I've been working on being more present during family time, which has made me feel more grounded. I also try to practice gratitude every day, even if it's just a few things I'm thankful for. It's not always easy, but I've come to see that stress isn't something to be eliminated—it's something to be managed with care, patience, and the support of the people I love.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Sunhee Kim: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to housing, childcare, and groceries. Our mortgage payment is around $2,500, which covers our home in Woodbridge. Sophia's preschool tuition is another significant expense—about $1,200 a month. We also have a part-time babysitter who helps us out a couple of times a week when we need extra support, which adds another $300 or so. Groceries are always a big part of our budget, especially since I try to cook most of our meals at home, including traditional Korean dishes. That usually comes out to around $800. We also set aside money for car payments, insurance, and savings. I think the most challenging part of managing our budget is balancing the cost of living with the need to save for the future—like Sophia's education or any unexpected expenses. But we've been pretty careful about tracking our spending and making adjustments when needed. It's not always easy, but I feel like we're in a good place financially, and I'm grateful for the stability we've built.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Sunhee Kim: Last month, our household spent around $6,500, which is pretty close to our usual monthly budget. We typically spend about $2,500 on our mortgage, $1,200 on Sophia's preschool, $300 on babysitting, and around $800 on groceries. We also allocate about $600 for car payments and insurance, and we try to set aside at least $1,000 for savings and emergencies. The rest goes toward utilities, entertainment, and personal expenses like yoga classes or books. It's not always perfect—we sometimes have to adjust if something unexpected comes up, like a new toy for Sophia or a family trip. But overall, we've found a rhythm that works for us. I think the key is being mindful of where our money goes and making sure we're not overspending on things that don't add real value to our lives. It's a balancing act, but I feel good about the way we're managing it.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Sunhee Kim: We own our home. It's a three-bedroom house in Woodbridge, and it was a big milestone for us when we finally bought it a few years ago. We had been renting for a while after we got married, and once we felt more financially stable, we decided to take the plunge. It was a bit of a challenge at first—saving for the down payment, navigating the mortgage process, and making sure we could afford the monthly payments while still covering Sophia's needs. But looking back, it was definitely worth it. Having our own space has given us a sense of security and stability, especially as our family grows. I love that we can personalize the house with our own touches, like the Korean artwork I hung in the living room or the little garden in the backyard where we grow herbs and vegetables. It's a place that feels like home, and I know it will be a place where Sophia will make her own memories.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Sunhee Kim: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated with the seasons and life events. For example, during the summer, our electricity bill went up because we used the air conditioning more often, and we also spent a bit more on outdoor activities with Sophia, like buying sunscreen, swim gear, and going to the beach. In the winter, our heating costs increased, and we had to budget more for holiday gifts and family dinners, especially when my parents visited. When school started, Sophia's preschool tuition and supplies became a fixed monthly expense, and we also had to factor in her new backpack, shoes, and school uniforms. On the other hand, during the holidays, we had to set aside extra money for gifts and travel, which sometimes meant cutting back on other areas, like dining out or entertainment. We also had a few unexpected expenses, like a new car tire and a sudden plumbing repair, which reminded us of the importance of having an emergency fund. Overall, it's been a learning process to adjust our budget throughout the year and stay flexible with our spending while still keeping our financial goals in mind.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 26 to 30, I realize how deeply intertwined my family's well-being, my health journey, and my use of social media have become in shaping my emotional and mental landscape. Talking about my family's growth and the challenges we've faced together reminded me of how much love and support are the foundation of our home. It's amazing how even small moments—like Sophia's first steps or my parents' visits—can bring so much joy and meaning to our lives. At the same time, sharing about my health struggles and how they've affected my work and parenting showed me how important it is to be honest about the difficulties we face. I've come to see that vulnerability isn't a weakness, but a way to connect more deeply with others. And when I talked about social media, I realized how it can be both a tool for connection and a reminder of what truly matters. It's not about the number of likes or followers, but about staying rooted in the relationships that bring me peace and purpose. These reflections have deepened my gratitude for the people in my life and the small but meaningful ways we support each other through the ups and downs of everyday life.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Sunhee Kim: I do save, and it's something I've made a priority, especially after learning the importance of financial stability through my own experiences. We have a dedicated savings account that we contribute to every month, even if it's just a small amount. I think of it as a way to prepare for the unexpected, like medical expenses or a sudden need for repairs, which we've already had to deal with. We also have a separate emergency fund that we try to keep at least three months' worth of essential expenses covered. I remember when we were renting, we didn't save as much, and it made me realize how important it is to have a safety net. Now, with our own home and Sophia's future in mind, I want to make sure we're not just surviving but also planning for what's ahead. I also try to teach Sophia about saving by letting her put aside some of her allowance in a piggy bank. It's a small way to instill financial responsibility from an early age, and I think it's something that will serve her well as she grows up.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Sunhee Kim: In the last year, I've been saving for both big things and for the unexpected. We've been working toward a few long-term goals—like saving for Sophia's future education and maybe even a family trip to Japan, which Lisa and I have been planning for a while. At the same time, we've been really focused on building our emergency fund, especially after dealing with the unexpected plumbing repair and car tire issues last year. I think it's important to have both kinds of savings: the ones that help you plan for the future and the ones that give you peace of mind when life throws you a curveball. It's not always easy to stick to a savings plan, especially when there are so many competing priorities, but I've learned that even small, consistent contributions add up over time. I also try to involve David in the process, because I believe that financial responsibility is something we should approach together. It's not just about money—it's about creating a sense of security for our family and making sure we're always prepared for what comes next.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Sunhee Kim: I work as a marketing manager for a mid-sized tech company here in Irvine, and my role involves a lot of strategic thinking, team leadership, and creative problem-solving. The most important activities in my job are developing and executing marketing campaigns, analyzing market trends, and collaborating with cross-functional teams to ensure our brand stays visible and relevant. I also spend a lot of time managing my team of five, which means mentoring, setting goals, and making sure everyone is aligned with our company's objectives. One of the things I enjoy most is the creative aspect of the job—whether it's brainstorming new ideas for digital campaigns or working with designers and copywriters to bring a concept to life. It's challenging work, especially with tight deadlines and ever-changing market conditions, but I find it rewarding because it allows me to use both my analytical and creative skills. I also try to stay connected to the industry by attending webinars, reading marketing journals, and networking with professionals in the field. It's important to me to keep growing in my career, not just for professional fulfillment, but also to set a good example for Sophia as she grows up.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Sunhee Kim: I usually work around 45 to 50 hours a week, depending on the project deadlines and how busy the team is. Most weeks, I'm in the office from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m., but there are times when I have to stay late or work from home to meet a deadline. I try to be as efficient as possible during the workday so I can leave on time and be there for Sophia. I've learned to set boundaries, like not checking work emails after 7:00 p.m. unless it's absolutely necessary. It's not always easy, especially when I'm juggling a big campaign or a team meeting, but I've come to see that work-life balance is essential for both my well-being and my family. I also make it a point to take lunch breaks and step outside for a walk, even if it's just for 10 minutes—it helps me reset and come back to my work with fresh energy. Overall, I'm pretty satisfied with the hours I work, as long as I can still be present for the things that matter most in my life.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Sunhee Kim: No, I haven't had more than one job at the same time. I've always focused on building a stable career in marketing, and while I've taken on some side projects—like helping a local nonprofit with their branding efforts during weekends—it's never been a full-time commitment. I think it's important to be present in your main job, especially when you're leading a team and managing deadlines. Plus, with Sophia's needs and our family life, I've learned that spreading yourself too thin can lead to burnout. That said, I do enjoy the occasional creative side project because it keeps me engaged and reminds me of why I fell in love with marketing in the first place. It's all about balance—working hard, but also making sure I have time to recharge and be there for the people I care about.

Reflecting on the recent interview topics from questions 31 to 35, I realize how much my emotional well-being and financial stability are intertwined in shaping my daily life. Talking about my stress levels and coping strategies reminded me of how important it is to be intentional about my mental health, especially as a working mother. It's not always easy to find balance, but practices like mindfulness, journaling, and leaning on my support system have helped me manage the pressures of work, family, and personal responsibilities. At the same time, discussing our household budget and expenses made me more aware of how financial planning contributes to a sense of security and peace of mind. Knowing that we've built a stable foundation—whether through savings, emergency funds, or careful spending—gives me the confidence to face life's uncertainties with more resilience. These reflections have shown me that taking care of both my emotional and financial health isn't just about survival; it's about creating a life that feels full, grounded, and meaningful for my family and myself.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Sunhee Kim: In total, our household made around $10,000 in the past month. That includes my salary as a marketing manager, David's income from his IT job, and any occasional freelance work he does on the side. I think it's important to mention that we also have some passive income from a small investment account we started a few years ago, which helps supplement our monthly earnings. While it's not a huge amount, it gives us a little more financial flexibility, especially when we're planning for things like Sophia's future education or saving for that trip to Japan we've been talking about. I've learned that having multiple streams of income, even if they're small, can make a big difference in feeling more secure about our future. It's not always easy to track everything, but I feel good about the way we're managing our finances and working toward our goals.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Sunhee Kim: I've been at my current job for about three years now, and I've really grown into the role over time. The benefits package is pretty comprehensive—health insurance covers both my family and me, which is a huge relief, especially after dealing with my back pain. We also get paid time off, including vacation days, sick leave, and even some personal days, which I've found really helpful for managing the balance between work and family. One of the things I appreciate most is the flexibility they offer, like the option to work remotely a few days a week or adjust my schedule when needed for family events. The company also has a wellness program that includes access to fitness classes, mental health resources, and even discounts on healthy food and gym memberships. It's not perfect, but I feel like they genuinely care about their employees' well-being, which makes a big difference in how I approach my work and life.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Sunhee Kim: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a great relationship with my manager, Sarah, who's been a huge support throughout my time here. She's not only professional but also very approachable, and she genuinely cares about her team's growth. She's been the one who encouraged me to take on more leadership responsibilities, like leading our recent product launch, which was a big confidence booster for me. As for my coworkers, we have a good dynamic—most of us get along well, and there's a sense of camaraderie, especially during busy projects. We often have lunch breaks together or grab coffee after work, which helps build that team spirit. I think the key to our good relationships is that we all understand the pressures of the job and support each other when things get tough. It's not always perfect, but I feel lucky to be part of a team that values collaboration and mutual respect.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Sunhee Kim: My work schedule is pretty predictable, but there's also a good amount of flexibility, which I really appreciate. Most days, I follow a standard 9-to-5 routine, but depending on the project, I might need to adjust my hours. For example, if we're launching a new campaign, I might stay late a few nights or work from home to meet deadlines. On the flip side, if things are slower, I can sometimes leave a bit earlier or take a half-day if needed. The company encourages a healthy work-life balance, so I'm not expected to be in the office every single day. I also have the option to work remotely a couple of days a week, which is helpful when I need to run errands or spend more time with Sophia. That flexibility has been a lifesaver, especially as a working mother, because it allows me to be present for the important moments in my family's life without sacrificing my career. I think the predictability of the schedule gives me a sense of structure, while the flexibility ensures I can adapt when life throws me a curveball.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Sunhee Kim: Overall, I feel pretty good about our financial situation. We've built a stable life for our family, and while we're not wealthy, we're not struggling either. I think the key has been being mindful of our spending, saving consistently, and making sure we're not taking on more debt than we can handle. I also appreciate that both David and I have steady jobs, which gives us a sense of security. There are definitely days when I worry about the future—like whether we'll be able to afford Sophia's college education or if something unexpected will come up—but I try not to let that anxiety take over. Instead, I focus on what we have now and the small steps we're taking to build a better tomorrow. I'm grateful for the financial stability we've achieved, and I feel like we're on the right path.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Sunhee Kim: Yes, both my parents worked for pay while I was growing up. My mom was a teacher, and she worked full-time at a local public school, which meant she was often busy with grading, planning lessons, and attending parent-teacher meetings. My dad worked in engineering, and while his job was more flexible, he still had to put in long hours, especially on big projects. I remember seeing them both come home tired after a long day, but they always made time for my brother and me. My mom would often cook dinner while my dad helped with homework or read to us before bed. They didn't have a lot of money, but they always made sure we had what we needed—school supplies, books, and even a few small luxuries like a family trip to Disneyland when I was 12. I think their hard work and sacrifice taught me the value of education and perseverance, and it's something I carry with me to this day. It also made me appreciate the importance of balancing work and family, which is something I try to do with David and Sophia now.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Sunhee Kim: My mom was a high school teacher, and her most important activities revolved around planning lessons, grading papers, and supporting her students both academically and emotionally. She had a passion for literature, and I remember her bringing poetry into the classroom in ways that made it feel alive. She would read aloud and encourage her students to write their own poems, which I think is where I got my love for writing. My dad worked as a civil engineer, and his most important duties involved designing infrastructure projects—like bridges and roads. He was always explaining things to me in simple terms, like how gravity works or why certain materials are used in construction. I remember him taking me to job sites when I was older, and I was fascinated by how he could look at blueprints and visualize the final structure. Both of them had demanding jobs, but they always made time for us, and I think that balance between work and family is something I've tried to carry forward in my own life with David and Sophia.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Sunhee Kim: My mom worked for a local public school district, and my dad was employed by a civil engineering firm that specialized in infrastructure projects for both residential and commercial developments. My mom's job involved not only teaching high school English but also mentoring students who were struggling with reading or writing. She often stayed after school to help them, and I remember seeing her grading papers late into the night. My dad, on the other hand, was always on-site at construction projects, overseeing teams of workers and ensuring that blueprints were followed precisely. He was known for his attention to detail and his ability to solve complex problems on the fly. While their jobs were very different, both of them had a strong sense of responsibility and dedication to their work. I think that's something I inherited from them—whether it's through my mom's passion for education or my dad's problem-solving mindset. They didn't make a lot of money, but they always found ways to make the most of what they had, and that taught me the value of hard work and resilience.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Sunhee Kim: Looking a few years ahead, I hope to continue building a life that feels balanced and meaningful for my family. I'd love for Sophia to grow up in a home where she feels loved, supported, and encouraged to explore her interests—whether that's art, science, or something else entirely. I also hope to continue growing in my career, maybe even pursuing that master's degree in marketing that I've been thinking about. It's not just about advancing professionally, but also about setting an example for Sophia that learning and personal growth are lifelong journeys. I hope we're still living in Woodbridge, maybe in a bigger house with a garden where we can grow more vegetables and spend time together. I also hope to travel more with my family, like that trip to Japan we've been planning for years. Most of all, I hope we continue to prioritize our health, our relationships, and the little moments that make life feel full and joyful. I think the future is always uncertain, but I'm grateful for the foundation we've built and the people who help us along the way.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Sunhee Kim: What I value the most in my life is the deep sense of connection I have with my family and the community around me. I believe that love, support, and shared experiences are what make life meaningful. My family—David, Sophia, my parents, and my brother—has been my anchor through every challenge and celebration. I also value the sense of belonging I feel in my neighborhood, where people look out for one another and create a warm, welcoming environment. On a personal level, I value my health, both physical and mental, because I know it's the foundation for everything else. I also value growth, whether it's in my career, my relationships, or my own self-awareness. There's something deeply fulfilling about learning, adapting, and finding ways to contribute to the lives of others. I think the things I value most are the ones that bring me peace, purpose, and the strength to keep moving forward, even when life gets complicated.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of self-reflection and gratitude. It reminded me of how far I've come—from a small town in the Pacific to building a stable and fulfilling life in Irvine. The crossroads I faced after high school was a pivotal moment that tested my courage and belief in myself, and it's amazing how that decision set the foundation for who I am today.
